column4: am new to debian-based distros. when installing a random app from source that isnt in any repos, is there an easy way to turn it into a .deb?
that would depend on your definition of "easy"
anything equivalent to writing a slackbuild or running checkinstall in slackware?

a .deb is just an archive with lots of files inside and a policy... if you plan to make *compliant* .deb packages you must follow the packaging guidelines.... that can be hard depending on the source organization
you have checkinstall in ubuntu but that doesn't make a *compliant* package
the only reason i want a .deb is so i can uninstall it, deleting files, fixing made symlinks, backing up conf files, etc..

checkinstall will do a trick, but maybe it is better to learn how to package properly so you can provide updates easily, upgrades won't destroy configuration, and you can distribute easily the software, even on ubuntu if it is free...
to make a compkiant package look at the Packaging Guide: http://doc.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/packagingguide/
oh, these debs are only for my own personal use

I am still inclined to learn how to make everything *the rigth way* even for my own use... I never know, I may purchase another machine, may use my package on one of my clients later... and that knowledge will prove useful...
but you may do as you see fit,. you may as well just zip the files for your application and you wont even need .deb.... just unzip to a folder into, say, /usr/local and you're done installing
or use checkinstall which is almost the same thing
but by making a proper package you can specify dependencies and have them installed automatically next time, you can use debconf to configure your package, etc etc

i always made packages the proper way with archlinux, setting dependencies, and stuff like that. with arch it was a breeze even for me. but i'm guessing with ubuntu i won't have that much control over my system
that would be your choice, you may have as much control as you need/want to
